<target_code>
Here is the code of new_connection_close_:
```c
static void
new_connection_close_ (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                       struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  mhd_assert (connection->daemon == daemon);
  mhd_assert (! connection->in_cleanup);
  mhd_assert (NULL == connection->next);
  mhd_assert (NULL == connection->nextX);
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert (NULL == connection->nextE);
#endif /* EPOLL_SUPPORT */

#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  if (NULL != connection->tls_session)
  {
    mhd_assert (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS));
    gnutls_deinit (connection->tls_session);
  }
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  MHD_socket_close_chk_ (connection->socket_fd);
  MHD_ip_limit_del (daemon,
                    connection->addr,
                    connection->addr_len);
  if (NULL != connection->addr)
    free (connection->addr);
  free (connection);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no use of compiler language extensions in the provided code fragment. The file only contains standard C constructs: a static function definition, pointer parameters to structs, preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef/#endif), normal function calls, standard logical/bitwise expressions, pointer comparisons, free(), and return-freeing of allocated memory. There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __extension__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), inline assembly (asm), GCC nested functions, variably modified types in file scope, or other vendor-specific keywords. Macros referenced (mhd_assert, MHD_socket_close_chk_, MHD_ip_limit_del) and external library calls (gnutls_deinit) could internally use extensions, but those definitions are not present in this fragment — their usage here is just normal function/macro invocation and does not itself prove use of a language extension. Therefore no code fragments from this snippet require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
